msDesc.head: Historical collections, A: Italian, 14th cent.; B: English, 13th-14th cent

physDesc.p: Composite: two manuscripts written in the 14th century, brought together by the mid century. Fols. 1–48 || fols. 49–244 || flyleaves.

supportDesc.extent: vi + 227 leaves (fol.i–vi, 225–6 are original flyleaves; fol.227 was a pastedown) 265 192

decoDesc.decoNote: Initials, red flourished in brown or red, in the same style throughout.

binding.p: Contemporary binding of wooden boards covered with white leather, with a chemise; traces of two clasps fastening to catches on outer edge of back board, and of chain fastening to bottom edge of upper board.

history.provenance: Pressmark 'C. 59' and 'Liber monachorum sancti Edmundi de empcione fratris Willelmi de Colcestr' in quo continentur subscripta. Videlicet ...' followed by a list of contents (fol. vi verso).
'C. 59' and 'Liber monachorum sancti Edmundi' (fol. 1r) written by Henry of Kirkestede, the 14th-century librarian of Bury St. Edmunds.
Bought from his executors by Sir Thomas Phillipps (1792–1872) , MS. 11257.
history.acquisition: Sotheby's 30 Nov. 1965, lot 16, with pl. of fol. 1. Bought.

recordHist.source: Typescript description by Bodleian Library staff.

ref.title: MLGB3: Medieval Libraries of Great Britain

listBibl.head: Printed descriptions:
listBibl.bibl: A. Watson, Catalogue of Dated and Datable Manuscripts in Oxford Libraries (1984), no. 542 (fols. 49-224)

msItem.author: Martin (Polonus) of Troppau
msItem.title: Chronicon pontificum et imperatorum
msItem.note: A copy of the latest version, C, ed. L. Wieland, MGH. Scriptores XXII, 1872, pp.397–474 (and see pp. 383, 386–90). The chronicle of popes is followed by the continuations for 1277–85 pr. ibid., pp.476–82.
msItem.rubric: Incipit cronica fratris Martini domini pape penitenciarii et capellani

summary.p: Historical collection, the original part (fols. 50–62, 66–67v, 72–205v) written before 1314, with additions in several slighly later 14th-cent. hands.

msItem.author: William of Malmesbury
msItem.title: Gesta Pontificum
msItem.note: Extracts, made ‘pro sola et una fraternitatis caritate’, see fol.58v.
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt cronice de archiepiscopis at episcopis Anglie. Composite secundum W. Malmesburiensem monachum

msItem.title: Lists of the archbishops of Canterbury to 1313, the deans of St. Paul's, London to 1314, and the bishops of London to 131
msItem.note: Added by the original hand, with continuations to 1323 (St Paul's) and 1354 (bishops of London).

msItem.title: Leges Edwardi Confessoris
msItem.note: Prologue and cap.1–32, 36–39, in edition of W. Liebermann, Gesetze der Angelsachsen I, 1903, pp.627–55, 666–70.
msItem.rubric: Incipiunt leges sancti Edwardi per Willelmum conquestorem regem Anglie approbate et confirmate

msItem.title: Descriptions of Britain

msItem.incipit: Insula Britannie cui quondam Albion nomen fuit per milia passuum octingenta
msItem.note: Preceded by:
Passage on the reasons for the downfall of the Britons
The description of Britain is not taken from Gildas.

msItem.incipit: Britannia sicut legitur inter insulas omnes

msItem.note: 34 wonders ending (fol.67) with no.4 of the list in the edition cited below, and omitting no.27.

A slightly shorter version of these three items is in MS. Rawl.D.358, fol.97–101, 15th cent., with ex-libris of John Whetamstede, abbot of St. Albans. A version of the second and third items is printed in Ralph of Diceto's Abbreviationes Chronicorum, in his Opera HistoricaI, ed. Stubbs (R.S., 1876), pp.10–15. No.4 of the third item is in the longer version cited by Stubbs.

msItem.title: Account of founders of English monastic houses before the Conquest
msItem.note: Pr. in Ralph of Diceto, Opera Historica II, ed. Stubbs (R.S., 1876), pp.210–12.

msItem.author: Ps.-Methodius
msItem.title: De initio et fine saeculi
msItem.rubric: Incipit prophetia Methodii et memoriale temporum
msItem.note: The commonly found brief recension of the revelations of Ps.-Methodius.

msItem.author: Vincent of Beauvais
msItem.title: Speculum historiale
msItem.note: Extracts, not all consecutive, from lib. XXXII, parts of caps. 105–6, 108–112, 115–24.
msItem.rubric: Pronosticacio de futuris temporibus secundum fratem Vincentium Belvacensem

msItem.author: 'Matthew of Westminster'
msItem.title: Flores historiarum
msItem.rubric: Incipit prologus in librum qui Flores hystoriarum intitulatur
msItem.note: Closely related to MS. Lambeth 1106, probably from St. Paul's, London (see Luard's edition (R.S.1890), vol.i, pp.xxvii–viii and passim) but often even more abbreviated than Lambeth. After 1298, like most of the other MSS., both MSS. follow the E(‘Merton’) text rather than Ch(Chetham), from which they derive in the earlier part. Many of the longer insertions in Lambeth are included, and at 1291 (fol.186v) the ‘Ordinatio regni Scocie’ is in the form addressed to the dean and chapter of St. Paul's. The bull of Gregory X, 1273, on Peter Scot, found as a separate item in some MSS. of the Flores (e.g. MSS. Fairfax 20, fol.6v; B.M. Cotton Claud. E. VIII, fol.10), inserted in Lambeth at 936, is here inserted at 1185 (fol.152). Apparently peculiar to our MS. are: (fol.159v, 1213) John's charter of submission to the Pope in a fuller form than in the other MSS., with witnesses, etc.; (fol.162, 1216) copies of three further charters of John; and:

msItem.title: Historical account of the rights of the King of England over Scotland
msItem.incipit: Ad maiorem evidenciam iuris et dominii
msItem.note: Perhaps the same as the separate piece in MS. BM. Cotton Claud. E.VIII, fol.260v. Cf. Robert of Avesbury, De gestis Edwardi tertii, ed. E. Maunde Thompson, (R.S. 1889), pp.286–90.

msItem.title: Annales Paulini
msItem.note: Beginning only (1307–8). Pr. from MS. Lambeth 1106 by Stubbs, Chron. Edw. I et II (R.S.1882), pp.255–66.
(i.e. Ralph of Baldock, bishop of London 1304–1313; cf.Emden, B.R.U.O.iii 2148 no. cxxv). This rubric added by a 'shaky' hand.

msItem.author: Adam of Murimuth
msItem.title: Continuatio Chronicarum
msItem.note: Extract: 1309 to mid 1334, ed. Maunde Thompson (R. S.1889), pp.14–74. Written in a different hand.
msItem.rubric: Ex Cronicis Ade Merimoz can. Lond.
msItem.note: Rubric added by 'shaky' hand.

msItem.title: Chronicle of England, 1335–40
msItem.note: Continuing the preceding item, but not taken from Murimuth. Written by a hand of the mid-14th cent. which also added on fol.65 two missing chapters from the Flores for which spaces had been left on fol.80v, 81.

msItem.locus: (fol.219–224v, followed by stubs of cancelled leaves)
msItem.title: Annals, 1341–63
msItem.note: Leaves ruled up for further additions, two years to a page, for years 1341–63, by Henry of Kirkestede, who made entries only for 1341 (death and election of prior of Ely), 1342, 1360 (death of abbot of Bury), 1361 (death of prior and 18 monks of Bury in plague; destruction of tower in gale, etc.).
Items added on plank or inserted leaves by three 14th-cent. hands
Historical pieces

msItem.title: List of papal legates to England, 1206–1317

msItem.author: Geoffrey of Monmouth
msItem.title: Historia regum Britanniae
msItem.note: Extract: Bk. XII.iv–xix, pp.518–535 in ed. of Griscom. 1929.
msItem.rubric: Extracta de cronicis Galfridi de Munemuta de historia Britonum…ex quibus elicitur cause ruine Britonum

msItem.title: List of papal bulls addressed to Kings of England, apparently arranged by subject, starting with Scotland
msItem.note: The earliest is of Honorius III (1216–1227) and the latest of Boniface VIII (1294–1303).

msItem.author: Ps.-Hildegard of Bingen
msItem.title: Insurgent gentes
msItem.note: The prophecy on the friars falsely attributed to Hildegard: see F. Vernet in Dict.Th.Cath. VI, col. 2470–1; preceded by a note on Hildegard's dates.

msItem.incipit: Regnum Scotorum fuit inter cetera regna
msItem.note: 44 lines. WIC 16547

msItem.incipit: Rex ego sum Malgo nuper extinctus modo vivo
Anno mille c ter x bis sexto dabit Eter
msItem.note: 4 lines. WIC 1139

msItem.incipit: M. semel et ter. C bis decem sex superadde
msItem.note: 5 lines

msItem.incipit: Phebus palescit virtus lune quia crescit
msItem.note: 4 lines.

supportDesc.collation: 7(14), 8(8) (originally a bifolium, 4–5 (fol.66–7) with 1–3, 6–8 later wrapped round it), 9(4) + 1 added at beginning, 10(8)–25(8), 26(10)–27(10), 28(4) (2–4 canc.) catchwords

decoDesc.decoNote: Initial Q with a face of a bearded man, and sprays with acorns and oak leaves extending into margins.
14th cent. annotations to fols. 76–217 include many crude marginal pen drawings apparently made by the shaky hand.

physDesc.accMat: Fol.iv, flyleaf, is a reject leaf from the present MS. of the Flores. On fol.iv verso, continued on fol.71, the shaky 14th cent. annotator wrote brief annalistic notes up to the year 1326. Fol.iv and v (blank) are a bifolium. For the other flyleaves and end pastedown (fol.i–iii, vi, 225–227, fol.iii verso, vi–vi verso originally blank) see below.

origin.origPlace: English, London (?) or Bury St. Edmunds (?)

msItem.locus: (fol.i–iii, vi, 225–227, fol.iii verso, vi–vi verso originally blank)
msItem.title: Commentary on Aristotle, De generatione et corruptione
msItem.note: (cap. vi-xi). The leaves were originally in the order i–ii, missing leaf, 227, 226, 225, iii, vi (blank).
